bibl.note: This is a letter dated May 18, 1838 from James King to his son Henry King. He instructs his son on the virtues of being a good soldier, as well as his various duties and responsibilities.

Rural Rest 18th May 1838.My Dear Son
div1.p: Before this time you have reached Calhone, the plaice of rendezvous, and by this I presume you have learnt a little of the reedements of a soaldier in camps; therefore if I give you a short treatice on the duties, acts, and performaces of a soaldier, it will be more perseptible to your understanding than would have been on any former occasion.

It is expected your officers will instruct you on all the various duties of a soaldier in camp; also, the rules & regulations, by law that are necessarily established, to keep good order and disciplin in the army. They will also inform you of the pennilities and punnishmints annexed by violating and disobaying such laws and regulation. Whilst learning what the various duties of a soaldier are; you should bear in mind, the soaldier that prides in his duty, will be always ready and chearfully perform it, whilst health permits,. therefore in I incourage you, by the love of duty to purform the part of a valient Soaldier. In treating on the love of duty I would not have you to think, you are to be at every bodies beck and call, and to do any thing that might call on you to do, no; that would show two much good natured ignorence;
I would have you to inspire confidence & stability in your self, and courage to suffer no imposition in any way.

I have been an old soaldier, and have seen, and know, many imprudent acts and deeds by soaldiers in the army; such as many have recieved severe punishment, others, with their carracters so defaimed that they bare Since I come in town I understand you are have all arrived at Calhone saft, and are all well, In presenting my respects to Capt Yoakum tell him if I would be pleased he would write to me- JaMKing
bare reproach where ever they go. Those occurrences frequently arrise, by two often indulging in little mischiviolus acts for amusements, and at length where checked. Your officers are under the disagreeably necesity of forcing them under gard, and purhaps, with wounded fealings sentince them to punnishment
My sone you are young; and unexperienced, let me treat the to be cautious, and act the part of an honourably Soaldier.

When I parted with you and the company my eyes ware overflowing; not that I was sorry, but overjoyed with the gratification of seeing so much patriotism and valour, inhailed in the youthful sones of Tennessee, by the lighted kindled flaimes of the old heroes of Seventy Six.-

Your officers are gentllmen of respectibility and I have no doubt but they will use their best efforts to provide for your general welfare, and should any of you be sick, I have no doubt but they would give all posible attention therefore I feal not the least uneasy about your welfair, and I flatter myself you have prudence and care enough to conduct yourself in a respectable & orderly manner so much so, as to merrit and recieve the applause of your officers & good will of the Soaldiers

What I have written I intend for you William & Albert to peruse, and regard it as matter of importance, coming from one who has had considerably experience in the service of his country. If any others wish interested to perusing it let them do so.

I wish you William & Albert assist each other as occasion requires, and act generously & fealingly towards each other-
My son, your mother has much feeling for you William and Albert on account of your youthful age, for fear you will be headless and careless, and get in bad habits; this I flatter myself will not be the case; she is purfectly reconsiled at your going, and are proud to think you have the pride of a soaldier, and cherrish the hopes that you will never degrad it- You Your brothers and sisters are often talking about you and wondering what you are about, and how your are doing, Charley are often talking about brother Henry's goin to shoot the Indians-

Myself your mother, Brothers & Sisters, Sarah and Martha are all in good health, Your Grandmother's, Your Aunt Jane & friends generally are all well, my respects to Snell & tell them I hear of no complaining at their homes- My respects and well wishes to Capt Yocum & Officers, and to the soaldiers generally,-

Your mother Brothers & sisters, Sarah & Martha joines me in love and well wishes for your's Williams & Aberts safety welfare and safe return home, write to me let me know where to direct letters to you, and what are the general movemts of the army
div1.closer: Your affectionate Father JaMKing to H.A.J King To all three of you, I have herd this say from farm and have read the fogoing lette us and agree with all the sittments therein contained, I say to my sover that we overall will and that I wish him to do his duty as I told him before he Hasted H D Jamison
